content.description: Two coins, A and B, each have a side for heads and a side for tails. When coin A is tossed, the probability it will land tails-side up is 0.5. When coin B is tossed, the probability it will land tails-side up is 0.8. Both coins will be tossed 20 times. Let <math alttext="p hat sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the proportion of times coin A lands tails-side up, and let <math alttext="p hat sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the proportion of times coin B lands tails-side up.
content.question: Is the number of tosses for each coin enough for the sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions <math alttext="p hat sub A, end sub, minus p hat sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>âˆ’</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to be approximately normal?

choices.label: Yes, 20 tosses for each coin is enough.
No, 20 tosses for coin A is enough, but 20 tosses for coin B is not enough.
No, 20 tosses for coin A is not enough, but 20 tosses for coin B is enough.
No, 20 tosses is not enough for either coin.
There is not enough information given to determine if 20 tosses is enough.

content.answer: No, 20 tosses for coin A is enough, but 20 tosses for coin B is not enough.

topic.text: 5.6: Sampling Distributions for Differences in Sample Proportions
